title: When will the UK have vaccinated 80% or more of its 18 and over population with a full course of a COVID-19 vaccine?
preds: Counting 42,087,971 today, leaving 224,065 to the target. At the current rate of just over 100,000 per day, this should resolve this weekend. Maybe Monday, given the lower weekend numbers.
Counting 41,673,647 today. Still on pace for August 27th.

Given the new numbers in question above, 42.3m is the 80pc threshold.  With 40.97m already vaccinated this means 1.3m are left.
Over 10 days remaining reporting this is 130k per day.  Rates are remaining at 160k per day, so well within end August timeframe Looking at numbers on the page:
41.3m and 76pc.  And looking at graph looks to be increasing by 0.25pc everyday.  So this is 8 days to get to 80pc.  Again around 27th or 28th.  So remaining with full on August forecast.  I’m not going to flinch…yet.
I count 41,204,255 using the new sources on August 20. It still appears this should resolve next week.

The change in numerator from the original source alters my forecast slightly (the original data included 16-17 year old in the numerator, which is now being manually removed by the update on August 19th).
This may be getting a bit interesting again: increase of yesterday only 0.2
At current run rate (from  70 to 75% was 16 days) it should be well within August

Major revision of my forecast. The last week hasn't really shown much slowdown and its been pretty steady for the past month, so expecting a major swing in the next 2 weeks is unlikely. Still allowing a small chance for an upset, but unlikely with current numbers.
Finally decided to settle fully on the August finish.
40,206,029 as of Aug 12. 7 day average 165.5k. Puts it 12 days out or Aug 24. Barring disaster it looks almost certain to be before Aug 31 now.

Humming right along I see. We are about 2,210,000 from the goal with 20 days remaining. Average is approximately 160,000 per day at the moment and so that puts us at 14 days of reporting to hit the 80% threshold. Expected value of August 31 (accounting for a slight drop in averages) is 850,000 in excess of the required 42,230,000. As of today, we can afford an AVERAGE of 110,500 per day and still make it. Every day we are above this adds more to the likelihood that we hit this in August. It's not a guarantee, but my "past August" percentage is so low as to be 0% on here. Probably close to 0.25%.
Number jumped to 75.7 (+0.4), it seems settled, going to 98% for August bucket

Second dose daily rates have remained fairly steady for the past month or so, with maybe a tiny decrease. Estimating about 0.28-0.29% per day. Since it's been so steady, I'm inclined to think it'll persist for at least the next few weeks. As of August 10th, 75.3% were fully vaccinated. Combined, this lands us at about August 26th. Vaccination rates would have to fall by about 25%! overall between August 10th and 31st,  in order to not meet the August 31 cutoff.

Now at 75.3pc or 39.8m with second dose. This gives an estimate of 52.9m for all over 18s.  And so 80pc would be 42.3m This leaves 2.5m left to get second doses to reach 80pc. 20 days left, so to reach by end August this is 124k per day. 
Average has been 155k, so needs quite a big drop off. At 155k per per day this is another 16 days which is Aug 27 Close. To end aug, but every day between now and then has to be 24k lower than the steady average for the past 6 weeks, which reflects the numbers of people who got the first dose 8 weeks ago.  First doses didn’t drop off significantly until 1 July, so done expect to run out of people to get 2nd dose before September.  Might start dropping over over the Aug bank holiday weekend, but 27th will be before then.
Joining the party a little late in the game.

Thank you @paulm @probahilliby @GMR for your helpful comments. First, going against *this* crowd seems a bit too courageous (= foolish). Especially after I ran I model with taking first shots from 8 weeks earlier (I didn't know in UK the interval between shots was that long)  – in this case, we would have  82.4 % on August 31.
I am humbly reverting to the crowd’s mean and will keep on looking out for signs if the 8 week or the 5 week model performs better…. (if the effect of 5 weeks earlier is >40% and the effect of 8 weeks earlier <60%, 80% won’t be reached before September).
I would presume that the rate has to drop by almost a quarter in the next 3 weeks for September to be reached.
It's going to be close and the rate is going down but it's harder for me to motivate it getting slower than picking up again in the remaining time. So I will stick to August over September.

Current daily rate puts this at about 28th August, with a slight uptick in daily rate when looking at the last 28 days. However I expect the rate will slow down as it gets closer to 80%, such that I think an early to mid September is more likely.  I'm a non-UK resident so I'm making assumptions that the vaccine is in reasonable supply if people want it, however if there are some areas of the UK that may experience local shortages this may also impact. What would make me change my prediction?
- A factor I haven't looked into deeply; is the behaviour of different age groups different? i.e. Are younger age groups more likely to resist or delay getting vaccinated?
 - I'm assuming the vaccines are manufactured in the UK and the supply is available. I haven't accounted for any potential disruption in supply.
 - More statistical analysis of the daily trend correlation and variance which is outside my skillset to look at in a timely manner.

Geepers this is going to be a tight one. I reckon we should get there on the 27th. 
Need to stay above 121k average so should be sitting nice

The increase is about 0.3 pp per day at the moment, which would mean ~20 days until we hit 80%. Today is the 8th, so that puts the expectation at around the 28th. Things may slow down though, I think the crowd is overly confident here.
Following the crowd as can't find actual dates when the second dose will be available.
UK take-up, mostly amongst young adults, is plateauing.

I am expecting an erratic daily rate from now on due to drop-offs through holidays and deferrals, but expecting this to be offset by increased bookings seen via the climb in first doses through the first three weeks of June. The advantages  of double-vaccinations for travelling abroad should also help encourage continued uptake. 
A fall to 150K moving av. this week is OK if the rate stays within 10-12% of the June levels, which would be within the margins seen last month. But it will be close. A lot will now depend on how those factors play out; if the drop-offs are too severe we could still miss the end of August deadline. I'm still with earlier forecast of 26th-30th and holding my breath.
Rate is slipping behind a little bit. Now on track for August 26. There's still 5 days of play, but need to watch the next week closely.

Yes, the current rate takes it to August 26 or 27 and has consistently been so, but there is a remarkable slow in the rate that may take it to September; furthermore, the slowing is consistent with the lag between first and second doses, it seems, which could indicate that the September bin is becoming an increasingly likely landfall for an 80% landfall.

7,14 and 21-day averages 160-170k daily doses therefore suggests on track for August. My forecast model suggests 27/28th of August to hit target if at 150-160k p/day  to build in a buffer from averages 126k of doses for 2nd August makes me think that there is a risk of a drop off thoughout August and potential to slip to September however this is only one data point and may be a knock on impact from lower weekend doses. Still have margin of safety if drops to 140k p/day then forecast to be 30 August.
Numbers still holding strong to complete in August. Checking back in a couple weeks. 160,000 per day is above the 140,000 or so we need to complete this in August.
3% every 10 days looks like the current pace, on track for around August 26th. But any small decline in the rate puts it in the next bucket so there's a decent chance it misses August.

Forecast mostly in line with my last updated model.
Increasing the chance of August https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1310947

It's not going to happen. 
Too much antivaxx, too many people living underground.

37,962k as of July 29. 7 Day avg 169,458. Current rate puts it 25 days out or Aug 23. Noting that it has slowed in the last week but I'm getting a bit nervous that the populace is behaving better than I anticipated (which is a good thing, but doesn't help my forecast). Broadly speaking uptake has been surprisingly consistent. Needs to be <126k/day for my forecast to hold so I'm moving to it being more likely before Sept 1
Updating as I had failed at basic arithmetic in my last prediction

First doses only hit 80% in mid-June. Assuming all of those people have to wait the full 8 weeks, it's not actually possible to get to 80% second doses before the end of August, but I'm hedging because the majority seem to think August is likely.
british news say 170K/day second dose with 5.2 million people to reach 80% as of july 29

Now at 71.1pc or 37.6m with second dose. This gives an estimate of 54.7m for all over 18s.  And so 80pc would be 41.5m This leaves 3.9m left to get second doses to reach 80pc. To reach by end August this is 121k per day. 
Average has been 170k, so needs quite a big drop off.
As at 27/7 uk vaccinated is 71.1%. Daily increase of around 0.3%. IF this continues 80% will be reached by late August.

Adding 5% to making it happen in August. Approximately 4,929,000 people left to get to the 80% threshold and current numbers are averaging 160,000-170,000 which is above the 142,000 average needed that I calculated 10 days ago. They really are maintaining pace on people showing up for their second dose, so I don't see why we would miss it unless something crazy happened. Current pace is 29 more days of vaccinations (170,000 per day) or 31 (160,000). That means that we would see this either August 24th or 26th and we have a few days of leeway for things so I continue to grow ever more confident in my original prediction. Will return in a couple weeks, likely with even more confidence in August being the one and only option.

As of Jul 24, the full course uptake was 70.3%. To get to 80%, we need another 9.7% uptake.
Historically over the past 4 weeks, the daily uptake has been almost flat, with an average of 0.32% / day (actually accelerating a bit to about 0.33% in the past week).
To get to 80% by Jul 31, that will require the uptake to grow to over 1.39% / day, more than 4 times the historical rate. Setting the probability of that to 0.
Continuing at the current rate of 0.32% / day, it is expected to get to 80% on Aug 23.
In order to get to 80% on or after Sep 1st, the daily rate will need to go down to below 0.25%, about 78% of it's historical rate.
Looking at the first dose uptake, it hasn't slowed down until the first dose uptake was around 84%. So I'm assuming that the second dose also won't slow down significantly. Still, leaving 10% probability of it slowing down enough to get to 80% in early September.
I think he target will be reached on the 16th of August plus or minus 5 days

As of Jul 25, the full course uptake was 69.9%. To get to 80%, we need another 10.1% uptake.
Historically over the past 4 weeks, the daily uptake has been almost flat, with an average of 0.31% / day (actually accelerating a bit to about 0.34% in the past 10 days).
To get to 80% by Jul 31, that will require the uptake to grow to over 1.6%/day, more than 5 times the historical rate. Setting the probability of that to 0.
Continuing at the current rate of 0.31% / day, it is expected to get to 80% on Aug 25.
In order to get to 80% on or after Sep 1st, the daily rate will need to go down to below 0.26%, about 86% of it's historical rate.
Looking at the first dose uptake, it hasn't slowed down until the first dose uptake was around 84%. So I'm assuming that the second dose also won't slow down significantly. Still, leaving 10% probability of it slowing down enough to get to 80% in early September.
Still on track for August 23rd, giving 8 days of play out of the 39 days remaining in the third bin.

Vaccinations still outpacing my original forecast, and mostly in line when I correct my forecast with a extra fudge factor. 
See https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1308115 The current fudge factor is still +0.12% given the slight increase in total population in the revision expected today (22 july) I think the 80% target will be reached one day later than I said before, ie on August 16th. Given on June 2 there was 50.7% and 26.4M fully vaccinated.  This can be extrapolated to a target of 41.7M fully vaccinated persons to hit 80% (we'll assume the population change isn't a factor). As of July 20, we're at 36.4M leaving 5.3M to hit 80%. For this to happen before the end of August, that's about 130k second doses/day required.  If we assume the vaccination rate is loosely tracking the first dose uptake with an 8 week lag (source: BBC More or less podcast - "The freedom day gamble"), we can infer the 2nd dose rate will remain about 150k per day until the end of August, as the 1st does rate dips below 150k on June 29th.  With a 2nd dose rate of 150k/day, this will tick past the target in 36 days, or August 25th. My position is based on the opinion that the 150k/day number is a baseline, and expect this to close about a week earlier than that.

So, from Thursday 22 July, vaccination uptake will be updated to use the mid-2020 population estimates. Which was slightly higher than mid-2019... 
This could affect the outcome, and is the sort of thing that tends to happen when questions are going according to forecast...
According to ONS: https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/populationandmigration/populationestimates/timeseries/gbpop/pop
UK population increased by ~0.42% mid-2019 to mid-2020, so perhaps the vaccination data we are reviewing will be adjusted to 99.57% of current totals?
I had allowed for 4 days drift for unknowns, but had not expected this one. I think there is room, but will look to see impact on % uptake on 22nd.

Now at 68.8pc or 36.2m with second dose. This gives an estimate of 54.7m for all over 18s.  And so 80pc would be 41.5m This leaves 5.3m left to get second doses to reach 80pc.
42 days to end Aug, which is 126k per day.  Current average is 170k per day which is well over the average, but there are 2 constraints to consider
1). The number of people who can get the 2nd dose is limited by the number who had their 1st dose 8 weeks ago.  In recent weeks there has been catch up for the reduction of time between 1st and 2nd dose from 12 to 8 weeks, so numbers now and in recent past could be a little high.  If we look back 8 weeks ago from now (mid May) about 200k per day we’re getting 1st doses.  So this is probably the maximum can happen
2) summer holidays which start this week.  People may have decided to get their vaccination quickly before the hips, but now people being on holiday and having schools out may reduce who goes.  However evidence for this seems limited
3) the number of infections and the fact that people with jabs are getting the virus, but not so badly, might be a good incentive to get the 2nd dose promptly.
4) removal of restrictions means people can do stuff, like have normal holidays, but feeling safe and being jabbed helps with this Therefore I’m going with end August, because I think everyone will go to get their 2nd dose as quickly as possible.  And because every day over the 126k means less needed the following days.  And a drop from 170k to 120k per day is a big drop that does ‘t feel likely at the moment (although it is possible).

Increased my August probability due to current rate - need over 140k/day to reach target currently over 170k/day 
Current 2nd vaccine wait time is 8 weeks  - 80% +8weeks is 11 Aug
Govt is asking the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation (JCVI) to provide urgent advice on halving the interval from eight weeks to four weeks
https://www.mylondon.news/news/london-covid-vaccine-wait-time-21022688
This would make over 88% of the 18+ population eligible to receive their vaccine before the end of August.
Unlikely that the JCVI will drop to 4 weeks though because 8 weeks is best for protection
https://inews.co.uk/news/politics/covid-19-vaccine-gap-doses-four-weeks-immunisation-nadhim-zahawi-1098474

We are now a few days ahead of expected forecast 26th Aug-2nd Sept, and the running av. still on track in July. I'm expecting some fluctuations over next few weeks as the holiday season and recent news about easing restrictions may affect schedules, but expecting a 7-day av. 155-185K to be maintained overall.
Anticipating a marginal increase in next two weeks to reflect the increasing rate of 1st doses late May, as 8-wk gaps between doses become the norm; if all goes well this will provide a slight buffer against missed appointments and other drop-offs. This may be critical, as I expect more variance in August due to holidays.
I'm looking for other warning signs that rates may drop, but I still think the issues with Delta cases, and the requirement for full doses to travel should be enough to keep encouraging people continuing with second doses as booked.
Target date range 23th August - 30th August.

Running the numbers one more time on this. Approx. 6,673,000 people still need to get 2nd dose to hit 80% and the daily average right now is around 161,000. There are 47 days of reporting remaining and we need 142,000 average in order to make it before 9/1 deadline. Basic math says we should make it in 42 days if the average holds and people keep their appointments. I'm thinking we reach it somewhere around 8/28 because of missed appointments. It won't take much to push us into September, so I'll be keeping a close eye on this. If our daily averages start dropping for any reason, that September number is going to need to creep up as well.
35,543k as of July 16. 7 Day average still holding. I'll hold too.
Latest vaccination data (67.1% on the 14th july) overtaking my already accelerated forecast (see comment https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1308115) I am increasing the weight of August

As of 7/15/2021 around 35M have been fully vaccinated with around 7M to go to reach 80% (approx. 42M). Using the latest 7-day average of 2nd doses of around 163K the UK should the 80% mark right around 8/27/2021. Factors such as increased fear of Delta could increase the vaccination rate while vaccine hesitancy could bring it down.  Sources:
https://coronavirus.data.gov.uk/details/vaccinations
https://news.sky.com/story/covid-19-two-thirds-of-uk-adults-have-received-two-vaccine-doses-health-secretary-sajid-javid-announces-12355759
https://www.bbc.com/news/health-55274833
slight move up in confidence as the second dose uptake rates are slightly beating expectation.

Vaccinations rates are faster than my model (see previous forecast comment). I am steadily increasing the likelihood of August for 80% target.
I think this will be reached around the 16th August give or take a week.

My forecast is based on the lag between first dose and second dose rates. It appears the numbers so far are lagged by about 10 weeks. Given the first dose hit 80% on June 16th, that would lead to second dose hitting 80% around August 25th. I'm reserving some probability in the later brackets to account for schedule slippage and conversion failure.
Anyone who has not been vaccinated at this point has made a decision not to be vaccinated. These goals are not realistic.
Not sure I should have diverted so much from Sept.

So it's a month on since my first look at this and I'd say that things are still on track for a August finish on the 80%.
second doses given so far this month have been very consistent in numbers pushing towards a 45 day finishline from now (25/26 Aug) . 
I was concerned about the potential for the summer holiday break to potentially delay the process however given the recent change in government attitude on quarentines it seems likely that what delays that do happen will be overtaken by people bringing vaccination dates forwards. further discusison about shortening time between vaccinations back to manufacturer guidance seems to indicate a potential for a sooner target date but still in August, daily rate for 2nd doses needs to be over 350k per day to complete before the end of this month ( which is possible from an infrastructure perspective ) which is an effective doubling of the current run rate, unlikely to occur.  Some possibilities of slippage (second dose supply... ) but this seems low right now so I'm pushing the August delivery to 95% https://coronavirus.data.gov.uk/details/vaccinations
34,541k as of July 9, 7 day average ~160k and holding puts it 47 days out or still Aug 25. Still holding forecast

Given eight week gap between first and second jab, 80% cannot be reached before around 8th August. Current r/r for second doses around 160k-170k which implies 80% reached in last week of August. Monitor - r/r appears to be slowing significantly.

Now at 64.9pc or 34.2m with second dose. This gives an estimate of 54.7m for all over 18s.  And so 80pc would be 41.5m This leaves 7.3m left to get second doses to reach 80pc. To reach by end August this is 134k per day.  Which is a little drop, in line with what I would expect over the summer holidays as people are thinking about other things. We also have a limit of who can get their 2nd does, because it depends on who has had their first dose.
8 weeks ago only 130ishk people were getting first doses.  So it’s not going to be possible to do wildly more than that number over the next month or so. But now government is saying they plan to lift most restrictions from July it’s hard to tell if that will spur people on to get the vaccine just so they don’t have to worry and can enjoy the summer, or it will make people, relax and they won’t bother.  Could go either way. So looking at it all ways it seems last week in August to first week or so in Sept is the likely time scale.  I’m going for later and therefore Sept because I think people will get distracted over the summer and then start thinking about it again when the schools go back.

We are aiming for around 42,216,000 with 34,027,000 completed as of today. Current average daily around 160,000 which leads to a simple outcome of 51 days to complete the vaccination. This is assuming no slowdown in the rate of vaccinations. 51 days from today is 8/27/21 which would end up leaving 4 days of cushion. Will need to continue to monitor. Lowered chance of August from 96% to 90% based on latest available data. Still holding out or hoping that we start to see an increase in 2nd dose pacing, but I'm doubtful.

Stronger forecast based on current rate of vaccination, move to 8-10w between doses, time past since current % and same % at first dose all pointing to August. 
UK want to open up and go back to 'normal' meaning people will be more anxious to finalise their vaccinations. All looking positive. I want to go higher but am wary of overconfidence

Wondering how previously infected (~7,5% of population) play a role in the statistic. As far as I can tell, giving a single shot as a "booster" is widely considered sufficient at this point, although a second dose is recommended. I believe that those with a single booster would then not be considered "fully vaccinated", pushing the date quite a lot in the future. Therefore sticking to the previous forecast.
Vaccination pace has slowed down. At the current rate, it will take around 50-55 days to reach 80%, which is around the last week of August.
Increasing my August probability based on current numbers

Looking at the latest % of 2 doses it seems like are speeding up a little compared to my forecast model described below. The error now is +1.3%. I guess the second doses are finally been done early with a shorter gap? I am revising my probability further placing august as a strong favourite now =====
My current forecast model of 2nd vaccinations predicts 2 of September as the date to reach 80% of adults:
It assumes that the 2nd doses done on the June 25 are the same as the 1st doses done on April 7 (a bit of a guess matching the dates, but an educated one); then it adds the daily average increase from 11+ weeks past to 61.2% (value on June 25) Observed| Date | Forecast

33.4 M are fully vaccinated. pace is slowing, average over 7 days around 160k-170k. still most likely to finish in July based on rate and conditions
33,402k a/o July 3; 7 day avg ~165k/day; 8,754k to go means 53 days at current rate or Aug 25 which is steady with last week so I'll hold the line

My current forecast model of 2nd vaccinations is doing alright this past week. 
It assumes that the 2nd doses done on the June 25 are the same as the 1st doses done on April 7; then it adds the daily average increase from 11+ weeks past to 61.2% (value on June 25) Observed| Date |Forecast

So projected date is still September 2nd which would give near even odds for September vs August. I am weighting towards August assuming that there would be a little acceleration of  2nd doses with the reduced interval gap between doses.

32.8M have now had 2nd dose leaving 9.2ish left to have theirs. rate of vaccination of 200k per day but trending downward. at 200k per day it would take 46 days to complete 80% which puts us in the middle of August.
Revised estimate. Daily 2nd dose shots have halved since my previous forecast. At current rate of 2nd doses, need about another 68-75 days from now.

It's still a close call, and could well tip into September, but I do expect 2nd dose rates to start to climb from this week on, as the 12wk interval gradually phases out (linked to the 1st dose decline in late March), and we move towards an 8-9wk gap.

32,460k a/o June 26 (61.6%). Rate is still slowing (7day avg is 162,868).  42,156k - 32,460k means 9,696k to go or 60 days from Jun 26, which is Aug 25, a full 2 weeks later than the trend pointed to 5 days ago. Total vaccinations are also trending down so it looks like more of an uptake issue than availability. Trend isn't moving positively for pre-Aug 31 so I'm moving 10% more likely it'll be in Sept https://coronavirus.data.gov.uk/

Now that 80-85% of adults have been vaccinated is a matter of understanding when these second doses will be administered. News of first dose vaccine is irrelevant (i am assuming people show up to their second dose). Looking at the graph "People who have received 2nd dose vaccinations, by report date" you can see a decline in average injections per week since the start of June.  This coincides with the decreases in first doses injected in the second half of March, ie 11-12 weeks before. So if i looks at 2nd vaccinations done in April, they started at 0.4-0.5% average per day in the first week, and reduced to about 0.2% afterwards (that makes sense as the vaccine supply was split between first and second dosers) So here is what i think. I assume that on the 25 of June (2nd doses =61.2%) we are vaccinating 1st dosers from 7 April (a gap of 11 something weeks). I add the same percentage increase to 61.2% as seen each day (day average of the previous week, too much noise in the actual daily %) in April, I calculate that we reach 80.2% on the 2nd of September (good, matches my previous forecast).  The main uncertainty is the gap of 11 something weeks between dates.

It will be tight, but a few factors now support the end of August (just):
The gap was originally 11weeks, measured at the dates reaching 50% for both vaccines. End of August would be ~10 wks. But many dates for the second jab can or have now been brought forward to 8 wks. There are also ‘Grab a jab’  clinics for younger people, and higher than expected uptake by under 25s. 
In a few few weeks almost all capacity can go to second doses, which will help shift the rate upwards. Still seems possible and the political will is encouraging. 
Edit: In fact, forget the political will; I think the population is taking it upon itself to be cautious due to the rapid influx of Delta, and the effects on travel over Summer.

We hit 80% of first-dose uptake on 6/16. Given the 8-week delay between that and the second dose appointment, it seems like the basic estimated number should be 8/11. That leaves 20 days of August to complete the vaccinations which should be plenty of time for the UK to get to 80% in that timeframe. Still not 100% convinced on this and there is more of a chance of slowing down than speeding up, so I've left a small window for the next month and will update if new information arises.

End of August still looks plausible, even if the rate of 2nd doses declines as 1st doses did through the second half of March. But I think a few factors could marginally improve the schedule.
The delta variant is now widespread. Second jabs for over 40s can now be brought forward to 8 weeks (over 50s and 'at risk' groups were already eligible). The entire adult population should have completed first jabs by 19th July - in line with the delayed lockdown easing - so there are strong political as well as health incentives to get the first round complete by then. In early July there should be increasing availability for the second doses as first doses taper off, which suggests other age groups will also be able to bring the date forward. Some groups may have this gap reduced further, but likely still in August.
So a potential for 80% by mid-end August.

Big swing from Sep to august due to changes this week. I expect 1st dose people to go to very low level by 1st August at current rate or above. At this point all doses go to 2nd doses and the current 8-12 week dose gap will reduce to the recommended 3-4 weeks for pfizer and unknown but shorter for AZ should be at 80% in August but have stayed in 60:40 range for now

Thanks to @GMR for first letting me know about the 8 week delay, which shifts my estimate from end of July to mid-August.

https://www.bbc.com/news/health-55274833

At some point yesterday the 80% first dose threshold was reached, we would expect to hit ~84% by the end of the month. From my initial forecast I said that doses may be brought forward for age groups that matter for the purpose of this question (<30). That has now happened, and if everyone was to come forward for their second dose between 8/9 weeks we would be done by 12th August. However I still think it's unlikely that will happen as it assumes:
1. Everyone who got a first dose will get a second
2. Everyone who gets a second will get it at the earliest opportunity Pessimistic on timing:
- The first point is clearly false but the extent to which it occurs is unknown. In 65+ age bracket where the rate of increase in second doses has become almost flat (less than 1% increase in a week), there is ~4% drop between first and second dose take-up. 
- If we assume that will be static then we will need to see almost 84% of the population first dosed to get to 80% second dosed. It will probably be another week before we reach 84% first doses, which takes us to the final third of August before those additional appointments open up.
- The second point is also demonstrably false because the we can see in the data that second doses for any given age group increase slower as time goes on.  Optimistic on timing:
- Anyone who gets a jab before ~4th July will be eligible for their second dose in August, so we won't need to have 100% coverage of those done so far, and those that are keen enough to get the second dose ASAP will buoy the numbers. For those reasons I still do not think it's more likely that 80% will have 2 doses by end of August under the current schedule. I think it will be close, but not quite there.  If the dosing schedule is brought forward again or we see 90% vaccinated by the end of June I might think otherwise.
re adjust for the chance that they will let everyone go to 8 weeks, not just 40plus

I completely stuffed up my last forecast by forgetting the 8 to 12 week gap between vaccines. So silly!
79.8% as of 16th June so 12 weeks for the under 40s is early September. Potential that this will be brought down to 8 weeks for all which could ring it into August just. I do feel that the younger population will drag it out a bit

Last two weeks of August still look plausible; 2nd dose rates are now starting to ease as expected, to reflect the decline in 1st dose rates from end of March, and if that continues down to 1.7-2.0% increase every 5 days I'd target 8-10 weeks from now. This also aligns with the minimum expected gap between doses. 
Most people over 50 have had their second dose already, so the 2nd dose rate will be dependent on ~18-50 yrs groups, which I think are likely to complete the course. My expectation is that the impact of the delta variant and summer travel requirements will offset any disincentives, and many wealthier families may even book second doses earlier to allow flights abroad (a small proportion but enough to keep a steady trend throughout July).
Any slight slowing from this will clearly push things into September though, when the issue of holidays abroad is negated, so it is still quite open.
At current rates, it will be about 40 days until the target is reached (roughly 12 million doses remaining, at around 300k per day). That puts the end date around July 25th.
Strengthened estimate as trend is continuing
Updating based on the jab rate since this question opened, and based on the news today on jab strategy target.

Last two weeks of August still looks plausible to me, if 2nd doses decline to approx 30% from current rates from next week, beginning to mirror 1st dose rates and factoring in the delay between doses. Overall uptake across age-groups is consistently high, and this should be maintained due to delta strain concerns and issues with flying and travel requirements.

Quick first assessment just to get on the board here. I'm not super familiar with the UK's policies regarding vaccines but have some reasonable ideas based on comparisons to the USA. 1. UK is much less vaccine skeptical than the US - I doubt we will see 80% in the USA this year because people are being idiots. So there is a higher chance of this happening than in the USA. People also trust the government more and understand the expertise. 2. UK still suffers from skepticism and the difficulty in getting voluntary compliance with anything. Getting people in for a second dose is always going to be tough because some people feel safe with just one, it's inconvenient, and each percentage increase in vaccinated people means remaining percentage is tougher to reach. So far no drop-off has been shown. 3. Delta variant worries may prompt people to get the second jab since efficacy jumps from around 30% to 60+% with that. Again, using my frame of reference from the USA I believe this will encourage people to get the jab. Overall I see a general slowing of first doses and that means the second dose will follow. 100% guarantee that we will not have every first does person getting a second dose, so that is a good leading indicator as @kevins points out below. I'm more skeptical of the continuation of current trends, so think we will see it in October or later but also happy to update should we see things continuing at current pace. Back in 2 weeks to see how things are faring.

- July 1st impossible given 3 week minimum wait for second jab
- July 31st 'effectively' impossible given the 8 week minimum likely wait (although that was only for AZ over 50s)
- Baseline theoretically latest date would be 2 weeks after 80% first doses, however some won't get a second dose so that target needs to be increased slightly
- Likely to hit 80% in ~2 weeks so mid september we might expect target to be hit as a baseline, and Delta variant news on requiring 2 doses likely to mean that only a small (2%?) fraction will not come forward for a second dose - Potential upside to be done in August if mRNA supply increases.
- Unlikely given Pfizer+Moderna supply constraints and need for most 2nd doses for under 40s (<1 million per week)
- 80% Adults double dosed is likely to be closing in on the cap of what will be reached anyway, so you'd expect momentum to be slowing as this number is passed Indicators that alter forecast:
- mRNA supply
- Number of <40s taking AZ

@Iwantatr8 @adamcohen9250   Exactly this.  Though I anticipate take up will slow, increasing the risk it is pushed into Sept or even Oct.

First stab (jab?) at this: Nominaly as of today there's 77% of first doses given and 53.6% of second doses given and something like 52.68m people to vaccinate to meet the criteria  That leaves 36.5 million more vaccinations to give (1st and 2nd dose), with a flat estimate of 600k per day that's 60days from today or so. I'll take that as an earliest date given that the roll out is not meeting 600k per day every day and there seems to be some logistical limits on the numbers that can realistically be vaccinated on a single day. Other items that may impact the speed of roll out are the possibility of increased distribution to under 18's (some are already being vaccinated in cases of family members being on the sheilding list) and the weighting / impact of the 1st dose / 2nd dose time lag.  The time between vaccines is being reduced (anecdotal) due to the rise in varients, this may be further reduced as the roll out gets to the end but there's diminishing returns on that. 
Other complications are that the government will not just stop giving 1st vaccines once 80% has been reached so there's likely to be more doses given.
So how to set more limits on the upper end of the banding - one way would to be review the rates for the first dose as it's nearly at 80% now and it's taken 78 days (since 21st March) to get from the 53% it was at then, like the second dose is at now. So the highest probabliity is 60 to 80 days from now, 
I guess there's also the possibility of a third dose to add into the mix... may delay things a little.
It'll take roughly another 60 days at the current trendline to hit the threshold. Barring any major steps, it should place it squarely within the month of august
Current trajectory implies around end July but possible that getting higher uptake in youngest people may be difficult.
300k per day on average 2nd doses and about 15 mn doses left, works out to be 50 days,

I am in the uk and just got my vaccine. I will be getting my second late in August. I think 2nd doses will start to slow slightly, partially reflecting the reduction in 1st doses ~10 weeks earlier. If this is maintained, with the 'India' variant incentive and desire to travel balancing out any younger age group hesitancy and summer holidays, then I'm expecting end of August as most likely.

I'm going to allow a slight drop-off in 2nd doses through late July as holiday/staycation season starts - not sure how much this will be affected by the desire to get the 2nd dose to allow foreign travel.

Projecting the 2nd dose line forward gets to July 16th for 80% of adult population with 2nd dose. 
Arguments for faster: 
- once 1st doses are done, 2nd doses can ramp up more
- Govt probably putting more pressure to speed up because of variant concerns, and there is a possibility that England has a stockpile that it can accelerate through. 
- Under 40s second doses are being brought forward to 8-week window rather than 12-week, as were over 50s. This could also happen for younger age groups. 
Arguments for slower:
- Possibly supply issues, but I don't know if that's plausible. 
- Maybe uptake issuess for younger age groups, but uptake has been very high so far.  Another way to look at it is that as of today (6th June) 77% of adult population have had the first dose, which means that, apart from a small dropoff between first and second doses, around 80% should have had their 2nd dose within 12 weeks. That would be at the end of august. If all the last ones were brought forward to 8 weeks, that would put the end at the end of July. So I think June and October are very implausible.
The linear trend seems to bring it close in proximity to August. So with any delays it may spill into August. Fatter tail in case the rate eases.

Just about possible in July, but much more likely by end of August, allowing people more chance to travel over summer. Having said that, allowing for a 6-wk gap in doses would push things into September.
Risky relative to crowd by it's my honest initial understanding.
It's a hedge on both of the above , variants have changed the original plan.

I expect vaccination rates for 1st dose to hit 80% between 20th and 30th of June. When that happens, It would have taken ~90-100 days for the rate to go from ~50% to 80%. We can take that as a baseline for how long it will take for people to go from ~50% (current) to 80% for the second dose. However, in the last 2 weeks there has been a surge in cases. Given that surges rarely end well, I expect the situation to get to a point where they ramp up the vaccination drive.

Means even people who struggle for time can nip out at lunchtime.

As @Ryan-Beck noted, the 1st dose daily uptake declined around  in the high 50% range so it doesn't seem unreasonable that could happen with the 2nd dose as well. It's worth noting that the uptake prior to this slowing was much higher (~.4-.9%/day down to .1-.2%/day) than the current 2nd dose uptake rate (.3%). If there was a 30-50% drop in uptake at the 60% saturation point that would slow the 60-80% march substantially, possibly into October, which seems unlikely but not improbable. If substantial re-opening were to happen before 80% are reached it could dis-incentivize stragglers from getting their 2nd shot. It looks to be a toss if it will be before or after Sept 1, but I'm putting weight into the trend slowing so will put 2/3 of balance for after and will check the trend line in 2 weeks (when it should be near the 60% mark)
At the current rate the UK would reach 42 million in mid-July, but as others noted, the rate will probably decrease quickly as it did with first doses.

Looks like the UK has very high rates of vaccine acceptance. And if it continues its linear trajectory for second doses it would hit in mid July.
